newsitem.title: UK: UK cable industry welcomes C&W-led merger.
newsitem.headline: UK cable industry welcomes C&W-led merger.

text.p: The formation of a major new UK cable player from a group led by Cable & Wireless was welcomed on Tuesday by British industry body the Cable Communications Association.

The deal brings together C&W's Mercury, British cable company Videotron, Bell Cablemedia and NYNEX CableComms and aims to provide integrated telecoms, information and entertainment services via a new company, Cable & Wireless Communications.
"This is clear evidence of confidence in the future of the UK cable industry," a spokesman for the CCA told Reuters.
"The broadband fibre optic network being laid across the UK is the most advanced in the world for delivery to individual homes," he added.
He said some six billion stg had already been invested in building the network and a further six billion stg of investment was planned.
"It works out at six million stg per day investment in building the national network," he said.
He added that fibre optic technology had significant advantages over existing technology, traditionally copper technology used for telephony.
"Cable telephony is making significant inroads into BT's business," he said.
He said that "60,000 subscribers are moving from BT to cable for telephone services", adding that on average it is 30 percent cheaper for customers to use cable.
"With digital broadcasting little more than a year away...the fibre optic network will be the most cost-efficient means of delivering a range of services to the home," he said.
